sections.1_story_intuition: Capitals and currencies are among the most frequently asked topics in competitive exams. Knowing the capital cities and official currencies of countries helps candidates answer static GK questions quickly. This section covers important capitals, currencies, and related facts for exam success.
2_key_definitions: Capital: The city where a country's government is based.
Currency: The official money used in a country.
Country: A nation with its own government and territory.
Official Language: Language recognized by a country's government.
Continent: Large landmass containing multiple countries.
Exchange Rate: Value of one currency in terms of another.
Eurozone: European countries using the Euro.
Dollar: Currency used by several countries.
Rupee: Currency of India and some neighbors.

7_traps_confusing_points: Mixing up currencies of similar names (Dollar, Rupee).
Assuming Euro is used in all European countries.
Confusing official and de facto capitals.
Mixing up capitals of neighboring countries.
Assuming all countries have only one capital.
Confusing currency symbol with currency name.
Mixing up capitals of South Africa (Pretoria, Cape Town, Bloemfontein).
Assuming all countries use their own currency.
Confusing exchange rate with currency name.

8_case_study_context.title: Eurozone: Shared Currency in Europe
8_case_study_context.explanation: The Eurozone is a group of European countries that use the Euro as their official currency. This makes travel and trade easier within the region, but not all European countries are part of the Eurozone.
